question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Decide whether the following statement is true or false. You
need not give a reason. All matrices in this question are square
$n \times n$.}

If $\displaystyle A = A^{-1}$ then every eigenvalue of \emph{A} is
either 1 or -1.
sols:
The answer is \textbf{true}.

We are given that $\displaystyle A = A^{-1}$ which implies that
$\displaystyle A^{2} = I$. Let $\displaystyle p(\lambda)$ is the
characteristic polynomial of \emph{A} and $\displaystyle m(\lambda)$
its minimal polynomial. Notice that $\displaystyle m(\lambda)$ divides
$\displaystyle q(\lambda) = \lambda^2-1$ (since the matrix itself
satisfies its minimal polynomial by the Cayley-Hamilton theorem).
Furthermore, \emph{p} and \emph{m} also share roots and these form the
only roots. Hence all the roots of \emph{p} must be a subset of the
roots of $\displaystyle q(\lambda)$ which are $\displaystyle \pm 1$.
These roots are the eigenvalues of the matrix \emph{A} and so the matrix
can only have these eigenvalues.

This statement is \textbf{true}.

If \emph{λ} is an eigenvalue of \emph{A}, then \emph{1/λ} is an
eigenvalue of \emph{A\textsuperscript{-1}} with the same eigenvectors
(\emph{Av = λv}, \emph{v = λA\textsuperscript{-1}v}, \emph{v/λ =
A\textsuperscript{-1}v}). Hence

\[\lambda v = Av = A^{-1}v = \frac1{\lambda}v\]

or, equivalently (since \emph{\textbf{v} ≠ \textbf{0}}),

\[\displaystyle
\lambda^2 = 1,\]

so \emph{λ = -1} or \emph{λ = 1}.
